MySQL Constraints
SQL constraints are used to specify rules for the data in a table.
Constraints are used to limit the type of data that can go into a table. This 
ensures the accuracy and reliability of the data in the table. If there is any violation between the constraint and the data action, 
the action is aborted.
Constraints can be column level or table level. Column level constraints 
apply to a column, and table level constraints apply to the whole table.
The following constraints are commonly used in SQL:

content_sections.title: NOT NULL
content_sections.content: - Ensures that a column cannot have a NULL value

content_sections.title: UNIQUE
content_sections.content:
- Ensures that all values in a column are 
  different

content_sections.title: PRIMARY KEY
content_sections.content:
- A combination of a
NOT NULL
and
UNIQUE
.

content_sections.title: FOREIGN KEY
content_sections.content: - Prevents actions that would destroy links between tables

content_sections.title: CHECK
content_sections.content:
- Ensures that 
  the values in a column satisfies a specific condition

content_sections.title: DEFAULT
content_sections.content:
- Sets a default value for a column 
  if no value 
  is specified

content_sections.title: CREATE INDEX
content_sections.content:
- Used to create and retrieve data from the database 
  very quickly
